Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Changes in criteria air pollution levels in the US before, during, and after Covid-19 stay-at-home orders: Evidence from regulatory monitors.

AbstractText: The widespread and rapid social and economic changes from Covid-19 response might be expected to dramatically improve air quality. However, national monitoring data from the US Environmental Protection Agency for criteria pollutants (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, ozone, NO<sub>2</sub>, CO, PM<sub>10</sub>) provide inconsistent support for that expectation. Specifically, during stay-at-home orders, average PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels were slightly higher (~10% of its multi-year interquartile range [IQR]) than expected; average ozone, NO<sub>2</sub>, CO, and PM<sub>10</sub> levels were slightly lower (~30%, ~20%, ~27%, and ~1% of their IQR, respectively) than expected. The timing of peak anomaly, relative to the stay-at-home orders, varied by pollutant (ozone: 2 weeks before; NO<sub>2</sub>, CO: 3 weeks after; PM<sub>10</sub>: 2 weeks after); but, by 5-6 weeks after stay-at-home orders, the concentration anomalies appear to have ended. For PM<sub>2.5</sub>, ozone, CO, and PM<sub>10</sub>, no US state had lower-than-expected pollution levels for all weeks during stay-at-home-orders; for NO<sub>2</sub>, only Arizona had lower-than-expected levels for all weeks during stay-at-home orders. Our findings show that the enormous changes from the Covid-19 response have not lowered PM<sub>2.5</sub> levels across the US beyond their normal range of variability; for ozone, NO<sub>2</sub>, CO, and PM<sub>10</sub> concentrations were lowered but the reduction was modest and transient.
